image.altText: Chanel Contos runs her fingers through her hair on stage a National Press Club.

items.synopsis: Across Australia, 58 women have allegedly been killed by men this year — sparking urgent calls for a national family violence register of offenders.

title.children: 'Stop with the trauma bait': Chanel Contos slams media for domestic violence portrayal

image.altText: police tape closeup

items.synopsis: A recovery operation is continuing after the 10-year-old boy died at the scene on Cleveland Street in Wahroonga.

title.children: Boy dies after being trapped under a school lift on Sydney's upper North Shore

image.altText: A woman holds a baby.

items.synopsis: A number of Australian families in Gaza have been told to head to the Rafah border crossing with Egypt if it is safe to do so, in the hope it may be about to open to some foreign nationals.

title.children: 'Seize this opportunity': Australian families in Gaza told to head to Rafah border crossing

image.altText: Israeli forces' flares light up the night sky in northern Gaza Strip

items.synopsis: What do you want to know about the Israel-Gaza war? Our Middle East correspondent Allyson Horn has been reporting from Israel along with the ABC team and is ready to answer your questions from 6:30pm AEDT.

title.children: Do you have questions about the Israel-Gaza war? Ask our correspondent

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Israeli military said 11 soldiers were killed in fighting in Gaza on Tuesday, the biggest one-day loss for the armed forces since Hamas gunmen attacked southern Israel on October 7, killing about 300 soldiers and some 1,100 civilians. Israel's Army Radio said most of the dead were infantrymen whose vehicle was struck by an anti-armour missile. The IDF's website featured images of some of the fighters killed on Tuesday. Meanwhile, the director of humanitarian organisation the Red Crescent, Mahmoud Al-Saadi, said at least three Palestinians had been killed in an Israeli military operation in the West Bank. Reporting by Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Eleven Israeli soldiers killed in fighting on Tuesday, IDF says, most since October 7

children.content: The Israeli military said 11 soldiers were killed in fighting in Gaza on Tuesday, the biggest one-day loss for the armed forces since Hamas gunmen attacked southern Israel on October 7, killing about 300 soldiers and some 1,100 civilians.
Israel's Army Radio said most of the dead were infantrymen whose vehicle was struck by an anti-armour missile.
The IDF's website featured images of some of the fighters killed on Tuesday.
Meanwhile, the director of humanitarian organisation the Red Crescent , Mahmoud Al-Saadi, said at least three Palestinians had been killed in an Israeli military operation in the West Bank.
Reporting by Reuters

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Qatar has mediated an agreement between Egypt, Hamas and Israel — in coordination with the United States — to open the Rafah border crossing on Wednesday, a source briefed on the deal has told Reuters. The Qatari agreement will allow foreign passport holders and some critically injured civilians out of Gaza through the crossing with Egypt, the source told Reuters. However, there is no time line for how long the border crossing will be open for evacuations, the source said. Qatar is not linked to other items under negotiation, including the release of hostages or humanitarian pauses. Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Qatar mediates agreement to allow opening of Rafah border crossing, Reuters source says

children.content: Qatar has mediated an agreement between Egypt, Hamas and Israel — in coordination with the United States — to open the Rafah border crossing on Wednesday, a source briefed on the deal has told Reuters.
The Qatari agreement will allow foreign passport holders and some critically injured civilians out of Gaza through the crossing with Egypt, the source told Reuters.

props.alt: An image of a gate closed at the Rafah crossing point

children.content: The Rafah crossing between Gaza and Egypt
(Reuters: Ibraheem Abu Mustafa)
However, there is no time line for how long the border crossing will be open for evacuations, the source said.
Qatar is not linked to other items under negotiation, including the release of hostages or humanitarian pauses.
Reuters

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Simcha Greiniman is a volunteer driver for an Israeli group called ZAKA, which helps with body retrieval, and is often called to attend emergency scenes and provide immediate assistance. When he heard there had been a serious incident near the border with Gaza on October 7, he immediately jumped in his truck. He didn’t know what he was driving into when he headed down to southern Israel. Within hours of arriving, his truck was full of dozens of dead people who had been murdered by Hamas terrorists. Since then, he’s spent nearly every day collecting and transporting hundreds of bodies for identification and burial. He recounts one horrific story: “I walked into the house and there was a birthday cake sitting [there] … and you look up to the [photo on the] fridge and think, 'Who had a birthday that day?'" he said. “We walk into the bedroom … and we see a family of five members in a circle hugging each other. “You can’t believe what your eyes [have] seen, you cannot understand the situation. “One second there was a party and the next, death in the worst way you can think of.” Mr Greiniman said his team was still going through Kibbutzim near the border, searching for bodies and remains of people who had been killed.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Israel's first responders recall the horror of what awaited them on October 7

children.content: Simcha Greiniman is a volunteer driver for an Israeli group called ZAKA, which helps with body retrieval, and is often called to attend emergency scenes and provide immediate assistance.
When he heard there had been a serious incident near the border with Gaza on October 7, he immediately jumped in his truck.

props.alt: A man stands next to an Israeli flag

children.content: Simcha volunteers for a search and rescue organisation called ZAKA.
(ABC News: Haidarr Jones)
He didn’t know what he was driving into when he headed down to southern Israel.
Within hours of arriving, his truck was full of dozens of dead people who had been murdered by Hamas terrorists.
Since then, he’s spent nearly every day collecting and transporting hundreds of bodies for identification and burial.
He recounts one horrific story:
“I walked into the house and there was a birthday cake sitting [there] … and you look up to the [photo on the] fridge and think, 'Who had a birthday that day?'" he said.
“We walk into the bedroom … and we see a family of five members in a circle hugging each other.
“You can’t believe what your eyes [have] seen, you cannot understand the situation.
“One second there was a party and the next, death in the worst way you can think of.”
Mr Greiniman said his team was still going through Kibbutzim near the border, searching for bodies and remains of people who had been killed.

image.altText: People crowd around a huge crater in a decimated urban area.

items.synopsis: A Gaza hospital director says more than 50 Palestinians are dead and 150 wounded after Israeli air strikes on the densely populated Jabalia refugee camp.

title.children: Israel says strikes on refugee camp killed senior Hamas leader, Palestinian officials say 50 people dead

image.altText: An Israeli army officer stands inside a narrow underground tunnel holding a firearm.

items.synopsis: Fighting underground could strip the Israeli military of some of its technological advantages and give the Hamas militant group the upper hand. Here's what we know about the complications Israel will face.

title.children: 'It was like I was fighting ghosts': What Israeli troops will face inside Hamas's labyrinth of tunnels

image.altText: Premier of Tasmania speaking to the House of Assembly.

items.synopsis: Tasmanian Premier Jeremy Rockliff categorically declares people in charge of regulatory and oversight bodies were not subject to misconduct allegations by the state's child sexual abuse commission of inquiry. He was responding to a statement made by Independent upper house MP Meg Webb under parliamentary privilege on Tuesday.

title.children: Tasmanian Premier calls on Meg Webb to apologise, says public servants wrongly named

image.altText: Meg Webb speaks at a press conference.

items.synopsis: Tasmanians had hoped the sexual abuse commission of inquiry would help clean up the culture inside state government institutions and departments, and help to stop child sexual abuse from occurring. Instead, there is a mess — and a lot of questions to be answered, writes Adam Langenberg.

title.children: Tasmanian government must reassure people their children are safe in state institutions

image.altText: A worker in protective suit and mask holds a pair of scissors above harvested cannabis.

items.synopsis: Demand for Tasmania's special "pot" plants is growing. This farm in southern Tasmania is set to triple its production, but it wants changes to strict advertising rules so it can reveal to customers that its product is local.

title.children: Demand is high for Tasmanian medicinal cannabis, with more than a million scripts written since it was legalised

image.altText: Matt Barker and Grace Tame watch another man speak at a press conference

items.synopsis: The term "landmark case" gets bandied around a lot, but the importance of GLJ v The Trustees of the Diocese of Lismore to survivors of institutional child sexual abuse cannot be overstated, writes Louise Milligan.

title.children: A landmark case opens the door for thousands of sexual abuse survivors — and lawyers are already firing off letters

image.altText: A man in a white button-up shirt walking with a tree and building behind him.

items.synopsis: Kerrod James Frahm had a "duty of care to protect his son" before the 11-year-old died of a brown snake bite in 2021, magistrate says.

title.children: Court rules father 'had knowledge of alleged snakebite' before his son died

image.altText: A burnt out bike sits on the porch of a home destroyed by fire in Tara.

items.synopsis: Firefighters were kept busy overnight, with dozens of bushfire warnings across southern Queensland and northern New South Wales, and more property losses confirmed. Follow live

title.children: Tara blaze downgraded in Queensland as authorities gain the upper hand on grassfires outside Sydney

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: She's just met with the Disaster Management Committee. There were fears earlier that Herberton's hospital may have needed to be evacuated, but the Premier says at this stage, that's not necessary.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Queensland Premier Annastacia Palaszczuk is speaking now

children.content: She's just met with the
Disaster Management Committee
There were fears earlier that Herberton's hospital may have needed to be evacuated, but the Premier says at this stage, that's not necessary.

props.alt: Queensland premier gives a live update.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Inspector Kent Barron from Queensland Fire and Emergency Services spoke from Warwick a short time ago. He says there are a series of fires south of Warwick, including the Delveen and Wallangarra blazes, which remain active. "This afternoon we have some crews coming in from Victoria and they'll be assisting us on the fire ground and as part of our incident management teams from start of shift tomorrow." He says he's found the bushfire season to be already "worse than 2019". "I've been in the region for 12 years and this season already is the worst we've ever had and just so spread out," he says. "It's been an incredibly trying season already."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Interstate crews arriving in Queensland this afternoon to help tackle fires

children.content: Inspector
Kent Barron
from Queensland Fire and Emergency Services spoke from Warwick a short time ago.

"This afternoon we have some crews coming in from Victoria and they'll be assisting us on the fire ground and as part of our incident management teams from start of shift tomorrow."
He says he's found the bushfire season to be already "worse than 2019".

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Max Tillman It's been confirmed that a Tabulam home has been lost in NSW's north-east. The RFS added that two other properties have also been damaged. Spokesperson Greg Allan said one property was destroyed in the Ogilvie Drive fire, but couldn't confirm exactly when it happened.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: One home lost, two damaged in NSW

children.content: Reporting by Max Tillman
It's been confirmed that a Tabulam home has been lost in NSW's north-east.
The RFS added that two other properties have also been damaged.
Spokesperson Greg Allan said one property was destroyed in the Ogilvie Drive fire, but couldn't confirm exactly when it happened.

image.altText: Firefighters battling a grassfire at the side of a road

items.synopsis: The bushfire threat continues for Queensland and NSW, but authorities hope favourable weather conditions will help control fires throughout the day.

title.children: NSW town 'literally surrounded by fires', as Queensland homes destroyed in blazes

image.altText: Clint and Michele Jennings

items.synopsis: Releasing the government's first review into Australia critical infrastructure networks, the home affairs minister says insider threats in hospitals, energy facilities and other essential networks have become one of the greatest threats to Australia's national security.

title.children: 'Disgruntled employees' targeted by foreign spies on dark web, as insider threats become major security focus

image.altText: SES, Police and CFA vehicles and personnel attend to a car crash on a sunny day. One car has an orange tarpaulin on it.

title.children: Driver who caused fatal crash 'confused' by doctor's order not to drive, court hears

image.altText: a herd of horses in waters

title.children: 'On an excursion, maybe?': Concerns children will see dead brumbies once Kosciuszko aerial cull begins

image.altText: Andrew O'Keefe, dressed in a suit and tie, arrives at Downing Centre Local court

image.altText: A close up image of a woman wearing a bright pink cloth face mask.

image.altText: An older man in a white T-shirt smiles while typing on a computer.

items.synopsis: Cryptocurrencies like Bitcoin have been on a tear higher in recent weeks, although they're still well down on record highs. Why are they rising and can it be sustained?

title.children: Retiree Mark lost out after buying Bitcoin near the peak. Now he's excited by its recent rebound

image.altText: A water tank with a black ladder propped against it

items.synopsis: South Australian police say forensic testing has confirmed suspicions that human remains found in the state's Mid North earlier this year are those of suspected murder victim Robert Atkins.

title.children: Human remains found in well in rural SA belong to suspected murder victim, police confirm

image.altText: Man pointing a gun.

items.synopsis: Vision a defence lawyer fought to keep secret is released, showing two service station attendants being taken hostage near Newcastle, and one faking pregnancy in order to be freed.

title.children: CCTV reveals moment 'gangster' took service station workers hostage with replica gun

image.altText: Bruce Lehrmann outside the ACT Supreme Court with a serious expression, wearing glasses and a tie. He has a beard.

items.synopsis: Data from the phone of a woman who police allege was raped by former Liberal party staffer Bruce Lehrmann has been received by his lawyers, a court has heard.

title.children: Alleged rape victim's mobile phone data handed to Bruce Lehrmann's lawyers

image.altText: A court sketch of a white-haired man wearing glasses seated in a witness box behind a microphone.

items.synopsis: The two-time Oscar winner angrily denies numerous allegations of abusive behaviour towards his former assistant and vice-president, who is seeking damages for emotional distress and reputational damage in a New York federal court.

title.children: Robert De Niro apologises for angry outburst in court as he denies abusing former assistant

image.altText: Nicholas walks along outside in a white button-up shirt.

items.synopsis: Nicholas Reed, one of the men convicted of setting fire to Old Parliament House in December 2021, will spend eight months in prison.

title.children: Man who set fire to Old Parliament House doors, caused $5 million in damage, jailed for eight months

image.altText: A woman and two children stand in front of a large red, metal sculpture.

items.synopsis: Batemans Bay's Sculpture for Clyde will offer an acquisitive prize at next year's event to rival Sculpture by the Sea and the Archibald.

title.children: Art trail's 'big kahuna' $100,000 sculpture prize to rival Sculpture by the Sea

image.altText: The exterior of the High Court of Australia in Canberra

items.synopsis: A woman who says she was abused by a priest in 1968 has won a High Court bid allowing her to sue the Catholic church for negligence.

title.children: NSW woman wins High Court bid freeing her up to sue Catholic church over alleged child sexual abuse

image.altText: A close up of the rear of a Tesla automobile with a California number plate

items.synopsis: The electric car maker wins a civil trial over allegations that its Autopilot driver assistant feature led to the death of a driver of a Model 3, a major victory as it faces several other lawsuits and federal investigations related to the same technology.

title.children: Tesla wins first US Autopilot trial involving fatal crash

image.altText: Three jockeys aboard three horses crossing the line in the Melbourne Cup.

items.synopsis: Why on earth would Australia's Big Four banks be expecting the Reserve Bank to lift rates on Melbourne Cup Day when Australians are buying less than a year ago and annual inflation is heading down, asks Peter Martin.

title.children: Australia's Big Four banks are betting on a Cup Day rate rise, and it's not because of inflation

image.altText: image of convicted terrorist Abdul Benbrika

items.synopsis: A notorious terrorist successfully challenges former home affairs minister Peter Dutton's 2020 decision to strip his Australian citizenship.

title.children: Convicted terrorist Abdul Nacer Benbrika wins High Court bid to restore his Australian citizenship

image.altText: Two men shake hands with red china and blue green Solomon Islands flags in the background.

items.synopsis: China's small police liaison team in Solomon Islands will increase to help provide security for this month's Pacific Games, while the Royal Solomon Islands Police Force gets another donation of equipment from Beijing including metal detectors and drones in a move that's causing concern in Canberra.

title.children: 'Progressively displacing Australia': China beefs up police presence in Solomon Islands for Pacific Games
